sentences: Sheena Shirley Easton (née Orr; born 27 April 1959) is a Scottish singer, songwriter, and actress.

sentences: A six-time Grammy nominee in the US, Easton is a two-time Grammy Award winner, winning Best New Artist in 1982 and Best Mexican-American Performance in 1985, for her duet with Luis Miguel on the song "Me Gustas Tal Como Eres".

sentences: She has received five US Gold albums and one US Platinum album.

sentences: Easton became the first and only recording artist in Billboard history to have a top 5 hit on each of Billboard's primary singles charts: "Morning Train (Nine to Five)" (pop and AC), "We've Got Tonight" with Kenny Rogers (country and AC), and "Sugar Walls" (R&B and dance).

== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Sheena Shirley Orr was born on 27 April 1959, at Bellshill Maternity Hospital in North Lanarkshire, Scotland, the youngest of six children of Annie and steel mill labourer Alex Orr.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: She has two brothers, Robert and Alex, and three sisters, Marilyn, Anessa, and Morag.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Her earliest-known public performance as a singer was in 1964 at the age of five, when she sang "Early One Morning" for her uncle and aunt and various relatives at the couple's 25th wedding anniversary celebration.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Easton's father died in 1969 and her mother had to support the family.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: According to Easton's website, despite her mother's heavy workload she was always available for her children: "Sheena always speaks very highly of her mum and the wonderful job she did in bringing up her and her siblings, including teaching them all to read at home before they were even enrolled in school.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: "Easton did not consider a singing career until she saw the movie The Way We Were, with Barbra Streisand.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Streisand's singing over the opening credits "overtook" the young girl and convinced her that what she wanted most was to be a singer and to have the same effect on others.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Her top grades in school earned her a scholarship to attend the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama in Glasgow, where she trained from 1975 to 1979 as a speech and drama teacher by day, while singing with a band called "Something Else" by night at local clubs.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: She chose to study teaching rather than performing, because it was a course of study that would let her perfect her craft as a singer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: In 1979, she married Sandi Easton, the first of her four husbands.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: They divorced after eight months, and Sheena decided to keep the surname Easton.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: That year, one of her tutors coaxed her into auditioning for Esther Rantzen, producer of the BBC programme The Big Time.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Rantzen was planning a documentary film to chronicle a relative unknown's rise to pop-music stardom.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Easton was selected as the subject for the programme; EMI executives awarded her a contract, and Christopher Neil was assigned as her recording producer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Deke Arlon became her first manager, and Easton spent much of 1980 being followed by camera crews, who filmed her throughout the process of her audition through to making her first EMI single, "Modern Girl".
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: In the course of the filming, she met and sang for Dorothy Squires, Dusty Springfield and Lulu, whose manager Marion Massey told her that she saw Easton as a potential TV star with her own series, but not as a pop singer for the 1980s as she lacked "rugged individuality".
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: The encounter with Massey (then Marion London), at which Lulu was present, was filmed and included in the broadcast, at which time Massey was not entirely incorrect, as "Modern Girl" had flopped on its release, peaking at no.56 in just three weeks on the UK singles chart in April 1980.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: However, once the programme aired in August 1980, "Modern Girl" was reissued and the track and its follow up "Nine to Five" both leapt into the top 10, disproving Massey's prediction.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: In a revised and extended version of this episode of The Big Time, broadcast in 1981; this special concluded with news of Easton's breaking into the American market.
section: == Life and career == | === 1959–1980: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Easton's first single, the disco-tinged soft-synth-pop tune, "Modern Girl", was released in the UK before The Big Time aired, reached number 56.

sentences: At the end of the show, Easton was still unsure of her future as a singer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1981–1982: "9 to 5", James Bond, Take My Time ===

sentences: The question was resolved soon after the show aired, when her second single, "9 to 5", reached number 3 on the UK Singles Chart and was certified a Gold single in 1980.
section: == Life and career == | === 1981–1982: "9 to 5", James Bond, Take My Time ===

sentences: "Modern Girl" re-entered the chart subsequently and climbed into the top 10, being certified a Silver single, and Easton found herself with two songs in the UK top 10 simultaneously.

sentences: "9 to 5" was Easton's first single release in the United States, although it was renamed "Morning Train (Nine To Five)" for its release in the US and Canada to avoid confusion with Dolly Parton's hit movie title song "9 to 5".

sentences: "Morning Train (Nine to Five)" became Easton's first and only number 1 hit in the US and topped both the Billboard Hot 100 and Adult Contemporary charts in Billboard magazine.
section: == Life and career == | === 1981–1982: "9 to 5", James Bond, Take My Time ===

sentences: "Modern Girl" was released as the follow-up and peaked at number 18, and before 1981 was over she had a Top 10 hit in both the US and UK with the Academy Award-nominated James Bond movie theme "For Your Eyes Only".

sentences: The song was nominated for an Academy Award and Golden Globe award in 1982 in the category "Best Music (Original Song)".
section: == Life and career == | === 1981–1982: "9 to 5", James Bond, Take My Time ===

sentences: Easton's US success culminated in her winning the Grammy Award for "Best New Artist" for 1982.

sentences: Easton's first three US albums, Sheena Easton (1981) (retitled edition of Take My Time), You Could Have Been with Me (1981), and Madness, Money & Music (1982), were all in the same soft rock/pop vein.

sentences: The title track from You Could Have Been with Me made it in to the US top 15; however, by the end of 1982, she saw her sales slumping.

sentences: Easton was one of the first artists to record "Wind Beneath My Wings" (included on Madness, Money & Music), which later was a hit for Bette Midler.

sentences: Then, in 1982, Easton undertook her first US tour.

No Sound But a Heart eventually did get released in the United States in 1999, with four bonus tracks, including Easton's contributions to the soundtrack of the 1986 film About Last Night, "Natural Love" and the Top 50 single "So Far, So Good".

sentences: 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street =
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===
== Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: In February 2013, Demon/Edsel Records (UK) reissued Easton's You Could Have Been with Me and Madness, Money & Music along with A Private Heaven and Do You in two compact disc packages remastered with bonus tracks, with the latter including the extended version of "Jimmy Mack" that has never been included on any of her reissues.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: In November 2014, a box set of Easton's first five albums in an original album series CD collection was released by Warner Music Group in the United Kingdom.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: In 2015 Easton embarked on symphony concerts with guest vocalists entitled "The Spy who Loved Me" with material from spy movies of the past and present and featuring Bond-style music with symphonies around the United States beginning in San Francisco from July 2015 and continuing into 2016.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: Easton also performed a small tour of dates during the latter part of 2015 in Australia featuring her Greatest Hits.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: In November 2016, Easton accepted the role of Dorothy Brock in the revival production of 42nd Street, which premiered on 20 March 2017 in London's West End Drury Lane.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: Lulu replaced Easton in March 2018.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: Easton performed at the 2021 New York State Fair, and two of her albums, Fabulous and an expanded edition of What Comes Naturally were reissued digitally through Apple Music.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: On Sept. 17, 2021, Cherry Red Records in the U.K. issued the three-CD box set The Definitive Singles 1980-1987, which collected all of Easton's English-language singles recorded for EMI, along with format-edit versions and some previously unreleased material.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===

sentences: Nov. 19, 2021, saw Apple Music make additional Easton material available digitally, with the collections Best Ballads and Greatest Hits, which feature material from Easton's post-1987 era with MCA/Universal.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–present: The Spy Who Loved Me, 42nd Street ===
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Easton has been married four times and has two adopted children.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Her first marriage was in Scotland to Sandi Easton at the age of 19.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The marriage lasted eight months.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Sandi Easton died in 1998, aged 48.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Her second marriage in 1984 to Rob Light, a talent agent, ended after 18 months.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Easton became a US citizen in 1992, carrying dual citizenship with the United Kingdom, and adopted her first child, Jake Rion Cousins Easton, in 1994.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Two years later, she adopted again, this time a baby girl she named Skylar.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In the summer of 1997, she met producer Tim Delarm while filming an episode of ESPN Canon Photo Safari in Yellowstone National Park and they married in Las Vegas in July 1997; the marriage lasted one year.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On 9 November 2002, she married John Minoli, a Beverly Hills plastic surgeon; they divorced in 2003.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Easton resides in Henderson, Nevada.
section: == Personal life ==
